plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid deciduous magnolia known for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that emerge in early spring before the leaves. It is widely cultivated in temperate regions and admired for its striking pink and white blooms.
plants.bloomingSeason: Early to mid spring (March to April)
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, native hybrid from Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer magnolias bloom before their leaves appear, creating a spectacular floral display that can be seen in many gardens worldwide in April.

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A small to medium-sized tree known for its brilliant red, spiky flowers that attract hummingbirds and other pollinators. It is native to South America and thrives in subtropical to tropical climates.
plants.bloomingSeason: Spring to early summer (September to December in Southern Hemisphere, March to May in Northern Hemisphere subtropics)
plants.location: Native to South America; cultivated in subtropical regions globally
plants.funFact: The name 'crista-galli' means rooster's crest in Latin, referring to the shape of the flowers resembling a cock's comb.

plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A perennial bulbous plant with bright yellow trumpet-shaped flowers, native to Europe. It is one of the earliest signs of spring in woodlands and meadows across temperate regions.
plants.bloomingSeason: Early to mid spring (March to April)
plants.location: Native to Western Europe, widely naturalized elsewhere
plants.funFact: Wild daffodils are toxic due to alkaloids, which protect them from herbivores.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: An Australian native tree that produces cylindrical flower spikes rich in nectar, attracting birds and mammals. It blooms prolifically during autumn and spring, even sometimes extending to summer.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round with peaks in autumn and spring (March to May and October to December)
plants.funFact: Banksias play a crucial role in their ecosystems by providing nectar for many native animals during times of scarce food.
